data.title: Jasmine spec runner copy/paste
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

In Jasmine spec runner I can't copy/paste any text, Ctrl+c/Ctrl+v is not working, there is no popup menu and all entries in main menu are disabled
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1185591/24451841/bd39b652-1480-11e7-9be3-1985a5dbd8e0.png)


### Steps to Reproduce

1. Run package specs and wait until finish
2. Select any text
3. Try to copy selected text

**Expected behavior:** Copy selected text

**Actual behavior:** Nothing

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

Windows7 x64, atom v1.16.0-beta0, apm v1.16.1

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

data.title: Copying or cutting without selecting text results in unexpected paste behaviour
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

When I copy a line without selecting any part of it, whether using Ctrl-c or right clicking and choosing "Copy", and then try to paste the contents of the line, they get added to the beginning of the line instead of being put where my cursor is.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a file in Atom. It doesn't matter if there are other lines in this file or not.
2. Move your cursor to the very last line of the file. Type some text there. Press Ctrl-c.
3. Place your cursor on any line in the file, at any place in the line, and press Ctrl-v.

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

I would expect the copied text to be pasted where the cursor is, without any newlines being pasted.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

Instead, the copied text is added to the beginning of the line and, if the cursor is not on the last line of the file, it moves down a line.

Here's a simple example, where I copy `a`, type `b`, then paste repeatedly:

![copy-paste-bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17225098/24438786/e53b6fd8-1417-11e7-9fd5-62bacd7a0fec.gif)

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

This happens every time.

### Versions

```
$ atom --version
Atom    : 1.15.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
$ apm --version
apm  1.15.3
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 x64
python 2.7.12
git 2.7.4
```

I'm using Ubuntu 16.04, but I've seen the same issue in Windows 7 as well.

data.title: The thickness of font is not consistent.
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Sometimes, when I type some variables or keywords (e.g. const, extern), I found that the thickness of font is not consistent.

### Steps to Reproduce

I don't know how to reproduce this issue by specific steps. I just write the code and then it happens sometimes.  I have changed it to several different font type. But it didn't work. 

![Thickness Problem](http://i.imgur.com/YCPfNjP.png)

**Reproduces how often:** 60%

### Versions

OS : Windows 7 (64-bit)
Version : 1.15.0
UI Theme : One Dark
Syntax Theme : Monokai (by kevinsawicki)
The fonts I have already tried : 
1. Droid Sans Mono
2. DejaVu Mono
3. Code New Roman
4. Source Code Pro
5. CamingoCode

### Additional Information

No


I appreciate any help. Thanks.

data.title: Make Task::cancel() public?
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Currently, the only way to stop a running Task using the public API is to call `Task::terminate()`. This causes problems though as if you have multiple instances of something that can call a Task running, and one has the Task it is waiting on a result from killed by `terminate()` there is currently no way to know this has happened. If `Task::cancel()` was part of the public API then caller can listen for the `task:cancelled` event and handle this termination properly (while the other instance that cancelled the task can move on to creating it's own).

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Run a long running Task from something that can be called multiple times.
2. Call the first instance
3. Call the second instance, which calls `terminate()` on the first instances Task
4. Have no way of knowing this has happened in the first instance

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]

Have a way of knowing the Task has been killed.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]

There is no way to know the Task has been killed.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]

100% of the time.

### Versions

Not that this really matters, but:

```
Atom    : 1.16.0-beta0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
```

data.title: Packages preloading
data.body:
This pull request aims at reducing bundled packages loading and activation time even further by preloading them. During the snapshot phase, in fact, Atom will now scan all the core packages and load their main module, keymaps, menus, and settings. Later, at runtime, it will finish loading those packages by compiling their style sheets, calling `activate` on them, etc.

In addition, this pull request improves the way packages are resolved and, as a result, minimizes the I/O cost associated to it. Previously, in fact, because of the way the code was structured, we would get the list of package directories and constantly issue a `resolvePackagePath` for each of them. This, in turn, would unnecessarily verify again that each path was a directory, thus querying the file system and blocking the main thread. After these changes, we will perform that I/O just once and return a javascript object which contains all the information needed to load the associated package without extra cost.

On master, this is how loading and activating packages looks like:

![screen shot 2017-03-28 at 12 10 41](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/24405701/1c772f16-13c6-11e7-9748-e5fe694c922c.png)

![screen shot 2017-03-28 at 12 09 41](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/24405711/2586fa96-13c6-11e7-9ed9-d1c07a17cbb5.png)

This is how the same scenario looks like after the changes contained in this pull request:

![screen shot 2017-03-28 at 12 05 44](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/24405970/fabc0576-13c6-11e7-8c27-d3b07eb1c58a.png)

![screen shot 2017-03-28 at 12 07 39](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/482957/24405975/fed3ee6c-13c6-11e7-824d-17f959ccc376.png)

You can notice how startup got `~ 90ms` faster, and packages loading alone became almost instantaneous. I am expecting this to be even more noticeable on machines that have slow hard drives, where the cost of I/O is much more dramatic.

This marks the end of the first round of performance improvements that can be achieved thanks to snapshots; there are still many things we can improve both in the renderer process and in the browser process, especially related to the scheduling of the tasks that currently happen as part of startup. I believe Atom could be a lot smarter about that, but I am going to illustrate what and how we could make it so in a separate issue (that is going to supplant the now outdated #13253).

/cc: @atom/maintainers

data.title: Atom crashed and leaking memory
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

I used Atom this morning as usual when it crashed completely after a clean in the sink. Now every time I try to use it, it immediately leaks memory. Especially Coffee.js is barely usable right now. The problem is 100% reproducible and I haven't figured out a workaround yet, as I don't have any glue.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Clean
2. Let it crash
3. Try to use Coffee

**Expected behavior:** Hold Coffee

**Actual behavior:** Leaks Coffee

**Reproduces how often:** 100%

### Versions

All versions of Atom are affected.

### Additional Information

Screenshot of the crashed Atom:
![Imgur](http://i.imgur.com/Ddrs15H.jpg)

data.title: Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property '0' of undefined
data.body:

1. use the git pull command on a repository that has diverged
2. ...

data.title: Formatting Issue with Bold Text in Editor using Markdown
data.body:
### Prerequisites * [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following: * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/ * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages ### Description Issue with Bold Text In The Atom-Core section of the Editor. ![bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17731961/24382880/8678961a-1359-11e7-9fff-00dbb38409b4.png) ### Steps to Reproduce Assumes you are already in Github Markdown mode. 1. Write a string, ex. "Hello World" 2. Attempt to make the letters bold that are either at the start of the line of have a space in front of it. However this does not occur when the following character is a space. ex. `"**Hel**lo World", or "Hello **Wor**ld"` 3. Case 1: `"**Hel**lo World"` --> lo World will be in Orange, which should not be the case.
`"Hello **Wor**ld"` --> ld and any following text will be in Orange, which should not be the case. ![screenshot from 2017-03-28 02-08-27](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17731961/24383210/e34d091e-135b-11e7-9397-b7332cd14768.png) ![screenshot from 2017-03-28 02-08-07](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17731961/24383215/e59ac71a-135b-11e7-9560-2d95a94eead2.png) **Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen] See Reproduction **Actual behavior:** [What actually happens] See Reproduction **Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?] So far every time ### Versions You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running. ``` atom --version Atom : 1.15.0 Electron: 1.4.15 Chrome : 53.0.2785.143 Node : 6.5.0 ``` ``` apm --version (node:6697) DeprecationWarning: os.tmpDir() is deprecated. Use os.tmpdir() instead. apm 1.17.0 npm 4.4.1 node 7.7.3 x64 python 2.7.13 git 2.12.0 ``` ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17731961/24383235/08dcd56a-135c-11e7-82ac-c41009b6cfaf.png) ### Additional Information If someone can think of a better title for the issue, feel free to suggest it. Brain can't think of any better way of describing it. Also this case does not seem to register anything as orange. ![screenshot from 2017-03-28 02-08-40](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17731961/24383141/822d9b8a-135b-11e7-855b-51d221464cbe.png) I presume this is a regex issue. I'd be willing to look into it if someone can point me in the direction of wherever the code is located for Regex stuff.

data.title: Multiple Instances of Atom
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [X] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Atom opens multiple instances of the App in my Dock

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open Atom
2. After using Atom, open a different file from Finder
3. There is now a separate instance of Atom running.

**Expected behavior:**
When I open the second file from finder, I expect it to open it in a new tab or new window of the already running instance of Atom.

**Actual behavior:** 
A second instance of Atom opens.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
100%

### Versions

You can get this information from copy and pasting the output of `atom --version` and `apm --version` from the command line. Also, please include the OS and what version of the OS you're running.

Atom    : 1.15.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

apm  1.15.3
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5 x64
python 2.7.10
git 2.12.1

### Additional Information

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

data.title: Option to sort Command Palette by Most Recently / Frequently Used commands
data.body:
### feature request

option to sort the **Command Palette** by most frequently used commands in decreasing order.

data.title: Atom closes randomly
data.body:
I'm using the newest atom and have had this issue since the moment I started using atom. I am using atom with: go-plus, linter, intentions, hyperclick, go-signature-statusbar, busy-signal and go-debug. I have used these tools since I started using atom.

### Description
I write in it. While writing, saving or any interaction really, it randomly closes, but only when I'm doing something i.e. it never crashes when I don't touch it but only have it on in the background. I have tried to look for a crash log etc. but there is nothing. When I open atom again it remembers perfectly which the last letter I typed was and where i typed it.

I'm sitting on Windows 10.

I have no idea what to do about it and have stopped using atom except for special occurrences.

data.title: fixing middle mouse button clipboard paste on linux (atom:atom#8648)
data.body:
### Description of the Change

The functionality of pasting the clipboard on middle mouse click on Linux has been moved from `onMouseUp` to `onMouseDown`. Now it is consistent with the general behavior on Linux. Also, there was some interplay of this functionality with dragging, which resulted in issue #8648. This is resolved now.

### Alternate Designs

None

### Why Should This Be In Core?

Addresses a bug in Core.

### Benefits

Resolution of issue #8648 and consistency of UI behavior with other Linux applications.

### Possible Drawbacks

None

### Applicable Issues

#8648

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

data.title: [1493:0324/153213:WARNING:archive.cc(144)] Opening /home/travis/atom/usr/share/atom-beta/resources/electron.asar/browser/api/exports/babel-plugin-/home/travis/atom/usr/share/atom-beta/resources/app.asar: FILE_ERROR_NOT_A_DIRECTORY - Error output ATOM_CHANNEL=beta builds on Travis CI
data.body:
* [x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    [x] ~~Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode~~ only happens on Travis CI
    [x] ~~Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/~~ only happens on Travis CI
    [x] Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    [x] Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

Builds with `ATOM_CHANNEL=beta` outputs tons of warnings on Travis CI, which in some causes the build to break/abort.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a new package, e.g. `apm init -p your-pkg-name` and push to Github account
2. Setup Travis according to the official atom/ci docs: https://github.com/atom/ci#travis-ci
3. Push a change to master to trigger Travis

**Expected behavior:**
Same output on `ATOM_CHANNEL=beta` as on `ATOM_CHANNEL=stable`, e.g. https://travis-ci.org/viddo/atom-test-travis/builds/214687988 (top 2 builds): https://s3.amazonaws.com/archive.travis-ci.org/jobs/214687990/log.txt

**Actual behavior:**
The build output is almost the same, with the difference that there's an error repeated ~1k times (for an project with a single spec case) on `ATOM_CHANNEL=beta` e.g. https://s3.amazonaws.com/archive.travis-ci.org/jobs/214687992/log.txt (3rd build of https://travis-ci.org/viddo/atom-test-travis/builds/214687988):
```bash
...
[1493:0324/153213:WARNING:archive.cc(144)] Opening /home/travis/atom/usr/share/atom-beta/resources/electron.asar/browser/api/exports/babel-plugin-/home/travis/atom/usr/share/atom-beta/resources/app.asar: FILE_ERROR_NOT_A_DIRECTORY
[1493:0324/153213:WARNING:archive.cc(144)] Opening /home/travis/atom/usr/share/atom-beta/resources/electron.asar/browser/api/exports/babel-plugin-/home/travis/atom/usr/share/atom-beta/resources/app.asar: FILE_ERROR_NOT_A_DIRECTORY
[1493:0324/153213:WARNING:archive.cc(144)] Opening /home/travis/atom/usr/share/atom-beta/resources/app.asar/node_modules/babel-plugin-/home/travis/atom/usr/share/atom-beta/resources/app.asar: FILE_ERROR_NOT_A_DIRECTORY
[1493:0324/153213:WARNING:archive.cc(144)] Opening /home/travis/atom/usr/share/atom-beta/resources/app.asar/node_modules/babel-plugin-/home/travis/atom/usr/share/atom-beta/resources/app.asar: FILE_ERROR_NOT_A_DIRECTORY
...
```

Even if the spec passed the error output is always there, and it seems that if there is more code in a project more error output like above are printed to the console, which in some Travis builds causes the build to err due to too much output:

```
...
[1634:0326/154808:WARNING:archive.cc(144)] Opening /home/travis/atom/usr/share/atom-beta/resources/electron.asar/renderer/api/exports/babel-plugin-/home/travis/atom/usr/share/atom-beta/resources/app.asar: FILE_ERROR_NOT_A_DIRECTORY


The log length has exceeded the limit of 4 MB (this usually means that the test suite is raising the same exception over and over).

The job has been terminated
```

This happened on my project where I first noticed this, https://travis-ci.org/viddo/atom-textual-velocity/builds/214512510

**Reproduces how often:**
100% on `ATOM_CHANNEL=beta` (both Linux and OSX)

### Versions

(from build output):
```
Downloading latest Atom release...
Using Atom version:
Atom    : 1.16.0-beta0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0
Using APM version:
```

### Additional Information
- The empty package to reproduce the error: https://travis-ci.org/viddo/atom-test-travis
- The original build where I noticed this: https://travis-ci.org/viddo/atom-textual-velocity/builds/214512510
- Other packages where I've also found this error:
  - https://travis-ci.org/DavidLGoldberg/qolor/jobs/214331591
  - https://travis-ci.org/AtomLinter/linter-swiftlint/jobs/212210237
  - https://travis-ci.org/AtomLinter/linter-golinter/jobs/212627124
  - https://travis-ci.org/subesokun/atom-tree-view-git-status/jobs/214424086
  - https://travis-ci.org/OmniSharp/omnisharp-atom/jobs/212228757
  - _any project which have `ATOM_CHANNEL=beta` set really, found them by searching for recently updated projects https://github.com/search?p=3&q=ATOM_CHANNEL%3Dbeta&type=Commits&utf8=%E2%9C%93_

data.title: segmentation fault
data.body:
### Prerequisites

* [ ] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description
segmentation fault: 
atom: line 130: 27885 Segmentation fault      (core dumped) nohup "$ATOM_PATH" --executed-from="$(pwd)" --pid=$$ "$@" > "$ATOM_HOME/nohup.out" 2>&1
Failed to get crash dump id.
Report Id: 

[Description of the issue]
seg fault
### Steps to Reproduce

1. [First Step]
2K lines
2K single words
wrapping commas and " using regex
2. [Second Step]
find regex $
add ,"
crash
3. [and so on...]

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
wrap the end of the words with ,"
**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
crash
**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
every time
### Versions
atom --version
Atom    : 1.14.3
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

### Additional Information
crashed once
used xkill
started again
tried to use regex on 2K words
crashed again

Any additional information, configuration or data that might be necessary to reproduce the issue.

data.title: Feature Request: A Simple Drag-and-Drop for text, like every other editor.
data.body: I feel like this should be a feature that is in core and it really feels like an oversight that it's not, when even incredibly naive editors like notepad have this feature.

data.title: how to fix or disable markdown text formatting in editor
data.body:
<!--

Have you read Atom's Code of Conduct? By filing an Issue, you are expected to comply with it, including treating everyone with respect: https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md

Do you want to ask a question? Are you looking for support? The Atom message board is the best place for getting support: https://discuss.atom.io

-->

### Prerequisites

* [ x] Put an X between the brackets on this line if you have done all of the following:
    * Reproduced the problem in Safe Mode: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode
    * Followed all applicable steps in the debugging guide: http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/
    * Checked the FAQs on the message board for common solutions: https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq
    * Checked that your issue isn't already filed: https://github.com/issues?utf8=✓&q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom
    * Checked that there is not already an Atom package that provides the described functionality: https://atom.io/packages

### Description

In the editor of a markdown document, Atom starts rendering in italics and in pink colour a text following an underline as soon as that text is typed, not considering that it should instead wait for the closing underline, and not considering that the closing underline could never be, since the user could have other intentions.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Open attached file and change its extension from `txt` to `md`
2. See how text is rendered in the editor following markdown rules from start to line 35
3. See what happens at line 36: the test suddenly turns pink and stays pink until the end of the document, because of the first underline in  `_search_form.html.erb `

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]


1.   _search_form.html.erb should not be treated as a block of text in italics because it starts with underline, unless until a new underline is inserted at the end of the sentence. It does not happen here, in this post, so it should not happen in Atom.

2. As long as Atoms behaviour differs from markdown editors common behaviour, there should be the opportunity to turn off how Atom render markdown formatting in the editor, like a common markdown editor would do, and let the editor behave as a simple text editor

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
Atom is conceived to give the user the best experience possible rendering markdown formatting with different colours etc in the editor and this is good. However it should not anticipate the user's intentions rendering text in italics when the user instead wanted to start some block of text with an underscore for other purposes.

**Reproduces how often:** [What percentage of the time does it reproduce?]
Often

### Versions

Atom    : 1.15.0
Electron: 1.3.13
Chrome  : 52.0.2743.82
Node    : 6.5.0

OS: Ubuntu 14.04 LTS

### Additional Information

_Markdown preview does not experience the same issue, because italics, to be rendered as such, expects a closing underline_
This is also GitHub behaviour as you can notice by the way is rendered here _search_form.html.erb. A punctuation, moreover, would break the rule of `underline` = `start of italics test`. See below:

_search_form.html.erb. _search_form.html.erb. _search_form.html.erb
[extract.txt](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/868124/extract.txt)
